thread.title: Only three break par in first round of City Am
thread.title_full: Only three break par in first round of City Am | savannahnow.com

author: Elmo Weeks
title: Only three break par in first round of City Am
text:
Photos Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News
James Wohler putts the ball during the Savannah City Amateur.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News
Parker Stone chips the ball toward a hole during the Savannah City Amateur.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News
2014 Savannah City Amateur champion, John Skeadas watches his ball after teeing off at hole one.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - Parker Stone warms up before teeing off at hole one. Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - Kevin Sethpun tees off at hole one during round one of the Savannah City Amateur Tournament. Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - Stephen McInerney tees off at the Savannah City Amateur. By Elmo Weeks
Trey Kent spends most of his time worrying about someone else’s scores, but he proved he’s got plenty of game of his own during the first round of the Savannah City Amateur on Saturday at Bacon Park Golf Club.
Kent, who caddies for Savannah’s Mark Silvers on the Web.com Tour, returned from a three-year hiatus from tournament play to shoot a 3-under-par 68 that leads the City Am by a stroke over John Skeadas III. In the first City Am round on the fully restored Donald Ross course at Bacon Park, only three players in a field of 96 broke par.
Behind Kent and Skeadas III, is Davy Clay, a two-time Wilmington Island Club club champion, who turned in a 1-under 70. Phillip Kennedy is fourth after an even-par 71, and there is a tie at 1-over par that includes defending champion John Skeadas II, Southbridge Golf Club club champion Rafael Array, Jeff Cowart and Joey Dewitt.
Kent, 35, played college golf at Armstrong State University from 2002-2005 and was a member of the team that finished runner-up in the NCAA Division II national championship tournament played at The Club at Savannah Harbor. He only recently regained his amateur status, and the City Am is his first stroke-play tournament in three years.
The last time Kent played in the City Am, he was the runner-up to Austin Meadows in 1995. He bogeyed his first two holes on Saturday, but calmed his nerves and played the next 16 holes in 5 under par, including four birdies in a row on Nos. 8-11.
“After those first two, I realized I needed to play golf, because I’m better than bogeying the first two holes,” said Kent, who is originally from Millen. “I called (Silvers) on Friday, and he gave me some good advice that helped. He said just try to keep it in front of you and don’t do anything stupid.
“It was a good round, but I feel like I left some out there,” Kent added.
Only one stroke behind Kent is another player who has not been playing much golf. Skeadas III played college golf at Davidson College but is currently in his third year working toward a law degree and masters degree at the University of Georgia, leaving him very little time to visit the links.
Skeadas birdied two of the three par-5 holes and only made one bogey in the first round playing alongside his father and former City Am champion Danny Nelson in the first round.
“I was fortunate to hit it pretty well and getting to play with my dad and (Nelson) (in) this tournament was a blast,” said Skeadas III, whose last tournament round was in July at the Golden Isles Invitational in Brunswick. “The course is a lot different, but it’s different for everyone out here. For everyone who grows up in Savannah, the City Am is a big deal, because when you look at the trophy you see a lot of the most important names for Savannah golf.”
Lurking only two strokes behind Kent is Clay, the club champion at the Wilmington Island Club in 2013 and 2014. He decided to play in honor of the late Don Vickery, who was the teaching professional at the Wilmington Island Club who taught Clay the game.
With the initials, “DV”, in marker on his golf ball, Clay, 29, was 4 under par through 11 holes before suffering bogeys on Nos. 12, 15 and 17. Playing in the City Am for the first time since 2006, he will be in today’s final pairing.
“Not knowing the golf course very well, I just hung in there making pars until I could make a couple of birdies,” Clay said. “I missed a couple of easy putts for par, but I’m definitely happy with the round. I love being in contention, so we’ll see how it goes.”
